docs.abstract: Blood samples from athletes at 2008 Olympics will be retested for new stamina-boosting drug called CERA (M)

headline.main: Beijing Games Blood Samples To Be Retested for New Drug

docs.snippet: The International Olympic Committee said it would retest blood samples collected from athletes at the Beijing Games to check for a new blood-boosting drug most often used by endurance athletes.
docs.lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee announced Wednesday that it would retest blood samples collected from athletes at the Beijing Games to check for a new stamina-boosting drug that would most benefit endurance athletes like cyclists and distance runners. So far, three stage winners at this year's Tour de France have tested positive for that drug, an anemia-fighting substance called CERA or Continuous Erythropoiesis Receptor Activator. It is a new generation of the drug EPO, which is banned by the World Anti-Doping Agency.

docs.abstract: Correction of October 5 profile of Heba Said Ahmed, Egyptian women who won gold medal for power lifting in recent Paralympic Games in Beijing, regarding reference to way in which she and her teammates were greeted in Egypt
docs.snippet: Because of an editing error, the Saturday Profile article, about Heba Said Ahmed, an Egyptian woman who won a gold medal for power lifting in the recent Paralympic Games in Beijing, misidentified the country in which she and her teammates were greete
docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, the Saturday Profile article, about Heba Said Ahmed, an Egyptian woman who won a gold medal for power lifting in the recent Paralympic Games in Beijing, misidentified the country in which she and her teammates were greeted by Egypt's first lady, Suzanne Mubarak, and the president's son Gamal. It was in Egypt, upon their return, not in China.

docs.abstract: Editorial contends that Federal Judge Ricardo Urbina has struck important blow for rule of law by ordering that 17 Uighur Muslims be freed from Guantanamo Bay, but Bush administration is fighting ruling to avoid having case become open window into outlaw world of Pres Bush's detention camps; urges appellate court to affirm Urbina's ruling and allow detainees into US

headline.main: The Rule of Law in Guantánamo

docs.snippet: The government is fighting a ruling to free detainees from Guantánamo Bay to avoid having the case become a window into the outlaw world of the camps.
docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Washington has struck an important blow for the rule of law by ordering that 17 detainees be freed from Guantánamo Bay. But the Bush administration is fighting the ruling to avoid having the case become an open window into the outlaw world of President Bush's detention camps. The detainees are members of the Uighur Muslim minority of China, which is violently oppressed by the Beijing government. They were swept up in Pakistan after the American invasion of Afghanistan and thrown into indefinite detention as ''illegal enemy combatants.''

docs.abstract: Photo of woman in Beijing, China, hauling couch home on tricycle

headline.main: Lovely Upholstery, and You Can't Beat the Mileage

docs.snippet: A Beijing woman hauls her new couch home on a tricycle. Assuming no steep hills or sudden stops, she may well enjoy it later.
docs.lead_paragraph: A Beijing woman hauls her new couch home on a tricycle. Assuming no steep hills or sudden stops, she may well enjoy it later.

docs.abstract: Liu Zhihua, former Beijing official who oversaw construction projects for 2008 Olympic Games, is given suspended death sentence for corruption in case that involved bribery and lavish living; Xinhua news agency says sentence will be commuted to life imprisonment if defendant shows good behavior; photo (M)

headline.main: Beijing Olympics Building Chief May Be Executed for Corruption

docs.snippet: A former official who oversaw citywide construction projects for this year’s Olympic Games has been given a suspended death sentence in a case that involved bribery and lavish living.
docs.lead_paragraph: A former Beijing official who oversaw citywide construction projects for this year's Olympic Games has been given a suspended death sentence for corruption in a case that involved bribery and lavish living, state news outlets reported on Sunday. Xinhua, the state news agency, reported that the sentence, suspended for two years, meant that if the defendant ''shows good behavior, his sentence will be commuted to life imprisonment.''

docs.abstract: Asian and European leaders convene in Beijing and seek to present unified front, promising mutual cooperation at next month's emergency financial meeting called by Pres Bush; China's Pres Hu Jintao calls for cooperative global response to financial crisis that he says has sent shockwaves through international financial markets; photo of Wen Jiabao with German Chancellor Angela Merkel (M)

headline.main: European and Asian Leaders Call for Unity in Facing Economic Crisis

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

docs.snippet: Asian and European leaders promised mutual cooperation at next month’s emergency financial meeting called by President Bush.
docs.lead_paragraph: On a day when European and Japanese markets suffered heavy losses, Asian and European leaders convened on Friday in Beijing and sought to present a unified front, promising mutual cooperation at next month's emergency financial meeting called by President Bush. Speaking at the opening of the two-day Asia-Europe Meeting, or ASEM, President Hu Jintao of China called for a cooperative global response to a financial crisis that he said had sent shockwaves through international financial markets.

docs.abstract: VanDam Inc has published new series of bilingual StreetSmart maps of Beijing, Hong Kong and Shanghai, China; photo (S)

headline.main: New Bilingual Maps For Visitors to Chinese Cities

docs.snippet: If your Mandarin is a little shaky and you plan to be visiting Beijing, Hong Kong or Shanghai anytime soon, then perhaps the purchase of a StreetSmart map would be a wise move. These latest offerings in the series of laminated fold-out maps are bilin
docs.lead_paragraph: If your Mandarin is a little shaky and you plan to be visiting Beijing, Hong Kong or Shanghai anytime soon, then perhaps the purchase of a StreetSmart map would be a wise move. These latest offerings in the series of laminated fold-out maps are bilingual and feature vivid graphics. They also automatically fold back into a compact size for easy handling. ''These maps are unique in three different ways,'' said Stephan Van Dam, the designer and publisher of VanDam Inc., which publishes the StreetSmart series, ''the clarity of their information design, their sexy covers and they make complex cities clearly understandable.''

docs.abstract: Jeremy Goldkorn travel article on day hikes in mountains around Beijing, China; photo; map (M)
docs.snippet: You can combine historical pursuits with some of the finest day hiking in China around the village of Fanzipai.
docs.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE do not usually think of outdoor activities when you mention Beijing. But the city is surrounded by a horseshoe of mountains, nearly a mile high, and fall is the perfect season to visit them. The mountains protected the city from barbarians on the plains to the north, west and east, and that was one of the reasons why Kublai Khan established his capital there in 1267, starting what the Chinese call the Yuan Dynasty. The city was then called Dadu. You can still see some ruins from that time at Beijing's Dadu Ruins Park between the Third and Fourth ring roads north of the city center. The park contains some replica stuff, and an old mud wall that dates from Kublai Khan's time.

docs.abstract: If you're in search of glasses, go a little north of Panjiayuan on the East Third Ring Road, to a place called Glasses City.

headline.main: Shopping Beijing: Designer Glasses for the Masses

docs.snippet: If you're in search of glasses, go a little north of Panjiayuan on the East Third Ring Road, to a place called Glasses City.
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the joys of living in east Asia is that shops are willing to work all day long to win your business. And they do it at a competitive price. Visitors have long taken advantage of the opportunity to buy stylish tailor-made clothes here, at rock bottom prices. But here's an even better deal: If you need a new pair of glasses -- or three -- you can take advantage of this same phenomenon.
